posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
I am trying to understand the implementation of motion followers on FRC products and since we don’t have the source code for TalonFX I am a little confused?

As far as I know CTRE Products run a position PID to current position of time sampled state and a velocity feedforward for that state  for the generated profile.

When I was looking for open source projects I saw the moteus project and documentation explained their way of closed loop control.

This is where I just got confused, they were getting both position and velocity targets for their closed loop control and using the kd with the velocity error which I have never seen before in FRC (probably I did not see it).

How does this approach differ from standard FRC way of following motion profiles?

As far as I understand this approach will allow you to follow a non zero velocity ending trajectory as well, is it true?

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
barkinvar:

kd with the velocity error which I have never seen before in FRC

kD is actually like having a kP controller on the velocity. Velocity is the derivative of position. The reason you don’t need to input the target velocity to your usual FRC PID controller is because it’s “guessing” that on its own using the previous position error and the current one. (currentError - prevError) / period = velocityError

barkinvar:

since we don’t have the source code for TalonFX I am a little confused?

CTRE uses an S-curve profile which is a bit harder to implement, but the WPILib trapezoidal profile should probably be more than enough for you.

link_counts.title: Motion Profiling in Command-based — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
barkinvar:

This is where I just got confused, they were getting both position and velocity targets for their closed loop control and using the kd with the velocity error which I have never seen before in FRC (probably I did not see it).

kD can be though of as a kP gain on velocity. A position pid can be better thought of as a PID with a target veloicty of zero. Motion profiles or moving inputs also generate a velocity reference and want you to keep velocity, so asking for a velocity of zero does not make sense. The solution is to pass velocity reference into both your feedforwards and feedback controllers, you will achieve significantly better reference tracking, resulting in the velocity error term you are seeing.

levyishai:

CTRE uses an S-curve profile which is a bit harder to implement,

Its less so hard but more so just tedious as they are are a lot more quations but they are applied in exactly in the same way.

barkinvar:

As far as I understand this approach will allow you to follow a non zero velocity ending trajectory as well, is it true?

Yes. This is how you track moving inputs, but there is the caveat that you must update the velocity and position reference together such that the velocity reference is exactly the first derivative of the position reference. (e.g if you want the controller to stay put in one place, the velocity reference must be zero at the end of the controller.) If you don’t do this correctly, the system will stabilize somewhere where you don’t want where the kp gains on position and velocity (kd) reach equilibrium.

I would actually suggest deriving the profiles by hand if you can’t find a good paper describing the math. Math is significantly easier to understand than code in terms of controls.

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
Alex_Y:

The solution is to pass velocity reference into both your feedforwards and feedback controllers

WPILib’s profiled PID controller does not use the velocity target while doing the calculations but rather it follows the moving target point. Since the target point is moving with the same velocity as profile calculated, it is probably going to achieve a similar result as I understand since

levyishai:

(currentError - prevError) / period = velocityError

but it still feels counter intuitive for me to calculate the velocity error from the position set points.

Another thing is that we use velocity feedforward but moteus does not. Wouldn’t it cause the controller to lag behind the target. Do they overcome it by doing torque control instead of voltage control?

barkinvar:

but it still feels counter intuitive for me to calculate the velocity error from the position set points.

Think of it this way:

velocity = d(Position)/dt velocityError = actualVelocity - desiredVelocity = (d(actualPosition)/dt) - (d(desiredPosition)/dt) = d(actualPosition - desiredPosition)/dt = d(positionError)/dt

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
barkinvar:

but it still feels counter intuitive for me to calculate the velocity error from the position set points.

I can totally understand why, think of it like this: if you’ll graph out each setpoint given to the robot, it’s very trivial to find the motion profile’s target velocity at any given moment without asking it for it. You simply take two points in the graph, find the slope between them and that should be the exact velocity setpoint given by the motion profile. It also handles non-zero velocity profile endings easily; if the rate of change in setpoint is constant and non-zero till the last second, the velocity target will also remain a non-zero constant setpoint.

barkinvar:

Do they overcome it by doing torque control instead of voltage control?

Yeah. Since torque is proportional to acceleration, zero torque should make you stay in your current velocity (if you apply kG, kS and other feed forward terms correctly). kV is used to cancel back-emf (basically the thing that makes motors slow down when the voltage goes down). You could say that just as a “side affect”, it also helps you reach a cruise velocity for voltage control rather than only maintaining it. Because in torque control there is no back-emf (the motor won’t slow down given a zero torque request), a kV wouldn’t really work and would be useless in most cases. If you’ve ever tried to SysId with TorqueCurrent control, you can see it’ll basically return zero for the kV. The kV equivalent for not lagging behind even without a kP for torque control is usually the kA.

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
levyishai:

It also handles non-zero velocity profile endings easily; if the rate of change in setpoint is constant and non-zero till the last second, the velocity target will also remain a non-zero constant setpoint.

But with the current implementation of profiledPIDController if I say go to position a with velocity b after it reaches the end position instead of going forward with constant speed it would fight to go back to position a I assume.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
In that case, if you intend on stopping to change the setpoint at the end of the path it’ll always do that. You’ll regardless need to change the position setpoint accordingly to match the integral of the velocity setpoint. If you’d stop only one abruptly, it won’t function as you’d like, as Alex mentioned:

Alex_Y:

If you don’t do this correctly, the system will stabilize somewhere where you don’t want where the kp gains on position and velocity (kd) reach equilibrium.

The real question should be; why are you generating a profile with a non-zero end velocity? I’d say the most common case is when switching between two controllers or setpoints in real time, and wanting the first one to try and maintain the highest velocity possible before going to the other setpoint. You might have a use case I haven’t thought of, but it should pretty much always work the same regardless on how you do it.

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
levyishai:

The real question should be; why are you generating a profile with a non-zero end velocity

I don’t really have a reason the generate a non zero end velocity. I just wanted to understand the what if case.

levyishai:

I’d say the most common case is when switching between two controllers or setpoints in real time, and wanting the first one to try and maintain the highest velocity possible before going to the other setpoint.

Yes, we sometimes do it if we want to switch between controllers during autonomous (drive to position with trajectory following then drive to pose with pid etc).

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
barkinvar:

Yes, we sometimes do it if we want to switch between controllers during autonomous (drive to position with trajectory following then drive to pose).

Yeah, autonomous was the exact same use case I had in mind. So, it should pretty much function the exact same way either way you do it, but I’d say deriving it from the position error is safer than inputting the target velocity by hand.

barkinvar:

WPILib’s profiled PID controller does not use the velocity target while doing the calculations but rather it follows the moving target point. Since the target point is moving with the same velocity as profile calculated, it is probably going to achieve a similar result as I understand since

Assuming the first part is true, it will track the target very poorly due significant phase lag. When the system is near setpoint, the kd gain will try to decelerate the system to 0, when that’s not what you want. You want the system to continue at the desired non-zero velocity as dictated by the motoion profile or moving input, hence why the velocity error term is required.

barkinvar:

but it still feels counter intuitive for me to calculate the velocity error from the position set points.

Velocity is the first time derivative of position. The above formula is the simplest way to take a discrete derivative.

levyishai:

The real question should be; why are you generating a profile with a non-zero end velocity? I’d say the most common case is when switching between two controllers or setpoints in real time, and wanting the first one to try and maintain the highest velocity possible before going to the other setpoint. You might have a use case I haven’t thought of, but it should pretty much always work the same regardless on how you do it.

Yes, but it is worth noting that you must have velocity continuity, which is not always trivial. Doing this but not well can result in velocity discontinuities which leads to unpredictable behavior.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
Alex_Y:

but it is worth noting that you must have velocity continuity, which is not always trivial

A good profile should be more than enough for this, which is already the intended use case.

posts.name: Barkın Var
posts.cooked:
Alex_Y:

Assuming the first part is true

It is not directly getting it as a parameter of a function, it is just a simple position PID but since the target position is changing with regards to wanted velocity and it uses

levyishai:

(currentError - prevError) / period = velocityError

this approach, all should result in the same mathematical value if I understood everything correctly.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Alex_Y:

Assuming the first part is true

You know you can read the source (or even the javadocs) and then you won’t have to (wrongly) assume and give bad advice.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
You know that you can read the entire discussion before replying to a post so you don’t have to take a post out of context and give a pointless reply distracting from the discussion?

My point is that tracking a moving target without using the velocity reference as suggested by earlier posts leads to poor tracking performance for reasons listed above, which needs to be notes when re-implementing profiles in a non- FRC context (like in the orignial post’s title)

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I understand what your point is.  Your point is irrelevant, because that wasn’t suggested earlier in the thread, and you are operating off of a misunderstanding of the library.
